channel.title: Mysql help
channel.description: i have just 1 question and that is how do i make people register on my forums before they can play

Really? Because I did it on my 317 back in '08 and it worked fine…
[/quote]It works perfectly; I’m not arguing going to argue that. It’s just a database safety risk.[/quote]Oh ok.

Read full topic

item.title: Mysql help
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:7, topic:330497”][quote author=Slave Scyth link=topic=426874.msg3134988#msg3134988 date=1266872416]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=426874.msg3134982#msg3134982 date=1266872085]
Well you can search Google for the things I tell you to do.

Ok, in your client, you are going to need to find the 317 client login methods, where it sends the username and password to the server.
Then before it sends the user and pass, you’ll need to MySQL query your database for the username and password, and check it against what the user entered. Then if they don’t match, end the method with a return statement and send a JMessage Dialog saying your forum name and that they need to register. It will be complicated to do if you don’t know how to do it, but it will be a learning experience.

Google those things in bold
[/quote]If you like SQL injection, go with his plan. If you don’t, and you prefer safety, make SQL logging server-sided.
[/quote]The forum would already be protected.[/quote]I have yet to hear of SQL injection via PHP, unless through forms, so yeah, it is protected. But connecting to your database via the client, (Java, NOT PHP), does have a possibility of SQL injection. If you query the database server-sided, though, it is near-completely safe.

Trust me, I’ve made this mistake before. And learned from it. I had the clients I had people download connect directly to my database, and a user contacted me telling me they SQL injected me. I checked the database, and what do I know? Under the ‘date’ column, set by the client, not the user, it said “YOU’VE BEEN HACKED”.

Read full topic

Well you can search Google for the things I tell you to do.

Ok, in your client, you are going to need to find the 317 client login methods, where it sends the username and password to the server.
Then before it sends the user and pass, you’ll need to MySQL query your database for the username and password, and check it against what the user entered. Then if they don’t match, end the method with a return statement and send a JMessage Dialog saying your forum name and that they need to register. It will be complicated to do if you don’t know how to do it, but it will be a learning experience.

Google those things in bold
[/quote]If you like SQL injection, go with his plan. If you don’t, and you prefer safety, make SQL logging server-sided.[/quote]The forum would already be protected.

Read full topic
